synergyScience.headline: Why Pushups + Situps Together Creates Complete Core-Upper Body Development
synergyScience.explanation: Pushups alone = chest/shoulders/triceps development, but weak core stability. Situps alone = ab strength, but no push pattern. Together = complete anterior chain development (front body strength). Military PT tests use this combo for reason: functional strength that transfers to real-world tasks. Research shows combined push + core training improves athletic performance 40% more than either alone.

synergyScience.neuroscience: Daily habit stacking = consistent progressive overload without cognitive load. Same exercises daily (no decision fatigue). Your body adapts: muscle endurance improves, then strength, then muscle size. Simplicity = sustainability.

stackingProtocol.timing: Morning (energy highest) or before shower (physical activity cue). 10-15 min total. Can split: morning pushups, evening situps if needed.
stackingProtocol.order: Pushups first (require more energy/stability), situps second (core is pre-fatigued, making abs work harder). Alternative: Superset (pushups → situps → rest → repeat).
stackingProtocol.bestPractice: Grease the Groove method: Instead of one max set, do multiple sub-maximal sets throughout day. Example: 10 pushups/situps every hour for 10 hours = 100 total each. Lower injury risk, better form.

progressionPlan.overview: Start with manageable baseline (20-30 total each). Progressive overload: add 5 reps/week. By Week 10, most reach 100+ each. Form over quantity - bad form = injury.

weeklyBreakdown.habit1Focus: Establish baseline pushups (can be knee pushups if needed). Track max set. 3 sets daily.
weeklyBreakdown.habit2Focus: Establish baseline situps. 3 sets daily. Focus on controlled movement (no momentum).
weeklyBreakdown.combinedGoal: Build daily habit. Consistency matters more than numbers. 20-30 each/day = solid start.

weeklyBreakdown.habit1Focus: Add 5 pushups to daily total. If doing 30, now do 35. Form check: chest to ground, full extension.
weeklyBreakdown.habit2Focus: Add 5 situps to daily total. Form check: no neck pulling, abs doing the work.
weeklyBreakdown.combinedGoal: Progressive overload starting. Soreness normal. Habit locked in. 40-50 each/day.

weeklyBreakdown.habit1Focus: 50-60 pushups daily. Can split into multiple sets. Notice chest/shoulder definition improving.
weeklyBreakdown.habit2Focus: 50-60 situps daily. Abs visible (if body fat low). Core strength obvious in daily life.
weeklyBreakdown.combinedGoal: Visible results. Shirts fit better. Confidence rising. You're an athlete now.

weeklyBreakdown.habit1Focus: 70-80 pushups daily. Experiment: diamond pushups, wide pushups, decline pushups (variation prevents plateau).
weeklyBreakdown.habit2Focus: 70-80 situps daily. Add variations: bicycle crunches, Russian twists, leg raises.
weeklyBreakdown.combinedGoal: Strength plateau breaking with variations. Body adapting to high volume. Performance peaking.

weeklyBreakdown.habit1Focus: 80-100+ pushups daily. Can bang out 30+ in single set. Upper body strength elite.
weeklyBreakdown.habit2Focus: 80-100+ situps daily. Six-pack visible (if diet dialed). Core rock solid.
weeklyBreakdown.combinedGoal: Identity shift: 'I do 100 pushups and situps daily' becomes who you are. Permanent habit.

commonMistakes: Bad pushup form (hips sagging, not going chest to ground - film yourself, check form)
Pulling neck during situps (hands behind head pulls neck - cross arms on chest instead)
Doing max sets to failure daily (overtraining = injury - sub-maximal sets safer)
No rest days (muscles grow during rest - 1 rest day/week recommended by Week 8)
Adding weight too soon (master bodyweight first - 100 perfect reps > 50 weighted reps)
Ignoring pain (soreness okay, sharp pain = stop - ego leads to injury)
Only doing standard variations (plateau after 8 weeks - add variations to keep progressing)

faqs.question: Should I do pushups and situps every single day?
faqs.answer: Weeks 1-6: Yes, daily (building habit). Weeks 7-10: Consider 1 rest day/week (muscle recovery). Long-term: 5-6 days/week optimal. Daily works for many, but listen to your body. Soreness okay, sharp pain = rest.

faqs.question: How many pushups and situps should I start with?
faqs.answer: Whatever you can do with good form. 10 perfect pushups > 30 half-reps. Test max set, then aim for 60-70% of that for daily volume. Example: Max 30 pushups? Start with 20/day total (split into 2 sets of 10).

faqs.question: What if I can't do a single regular pushup?
faqs.answer: Start with knee pushups or incline pushups (hands on counter/bench). Build strength for 2-4 weeks, then progress to regular pushups. No shame in modifications - everyone starts somewhere. Focus on form and progressive overload.

faqs.question: Will this actually build muscle or just endurance?
faqs.answer: Reps 1-20: Muscle growth. Reps 20-50: Muscle endurance. 50+: Cardiovascular endurance. You'll build muscle up to ~50 reps, then plateau. For continued growth past 100 reps, add variations (decline, one-arm progressions) or weighted vest.

faqs.question: Are situps bad for your back?
faqs.answer: Full situps with poor form = back strain. Better: crunches (partial range), planks, dead bugs. But situps done correctly (slow, controlled, no momentum) are safe. Alternative: Replace situps with plank holds (60-120 sec) for safer core training.

faqs.question: Can I split the reps throughout the day?
faqs.answer: Yes. Grease the Groove method: 10 pushups/situps every hour for 10 hours = 100 each. This approach reduces injury risk, maintains form, and fits busy schedules. Many find this easier than single 100-rep session.

faqs.question: How long until I see visible results?
faqs.answer: Strength gains: Week 2-3 (you'll feel stronger). Visible muscle: Week 5-8 (if body fat low). Six-pack abs: Dependent on body fat, not situps alone. Need <15% body fat for abs to show. Pushups build chest/shoulders visible by Week 6.
